questions.text: Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are seen in?
questions.solution:
Michaelis–Gutmann bodies are characteristic of malakoplakia.

It appears as laminated, basophilic concretions containing calcium deposits within the macrophages. The macrophages are periodic acid Schiff (PAS) positive.

Malakoplakia is a chronic inflammatory reaction resulting from acquired defects in phagocyte function affecting the urinary bladder. It can also be seen in other organ systems like the gastrointestinal tract, female genital tract, and central nervous system. It is seen in chronic bacterial infection, mostly by Escherichia coli or occasionally Proteus species. Grossly, malakoplakia takes the form of soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques. 

On microscopy, large, foamy macrophages with multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes are observed. The macrophages have granular cytoplasm due to undigested bacterial products. Intracellular deposition of calcium within enlarged lysosomes form laminated basophilic concretions, known as Michaelis–Gutmann bodies.

Image showing Michaelis-Gutmann bodies seen as concentric basophilic inclusions within macrophages.

Other options:

Option A - Chronic pyelonephritis is a chronic condition characterized by tubulointerstitial inflammation and scarring. On microscopy, thyroidization of cortical tubules is seen with dilated tubules, flattened epithelium, and colloid casts within them as shown below.

Option C - Urothelial carcinomas are seen commonly in the urinary bladder. On microscopy, various grades of disorganized urothelium are seen with enlarged and pleomorphic nuclei as shown below:

Option D - Myeloma kidney is also known as light chain cast nephropathy occurring in patients suffering from multiple myeloma. On microscopy, the light chain casts appear as pink masses, often fractured, and surrounded by macrophages and multinucleated cells as shown below:

Related Pearl: Pathological Named Bodies

Bodies Found in
Asteroid bodies Sarcoidosis, Sporotrichosis

questions.text: All of the following are true about disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) except:
questions.solution:
All of the following are true about disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) except for decreased prothrombin time (PT). In DIC, PT is typically prolonged.

DIC is a thrombohemorrhagic disorder occurring as a secondary complication in a variety of diseases. It is characterized by activation of the coagulation sequence that leads to the formation of microthrombi in the microcirculation of the body. 

As a result of microvascular thrombosis triggered by various causes, there is widespread deposition of fibrin in the circulation, causing vascular narrowing. This, in turn, activates fibrinolytic mechanisms via plasmin, resulting in decreased fibrin and increased fibrin degradation products (particularly D-dimers). Plasmin also consumes platelets and coagulation factors like factors V and VII, leading to decreased values of the same and subsequently prolonged PT and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT).

Some of the common presentations of DIC depending on the affected organs include:

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Dyspnea, cyanosis, respiratory failure
  • Convulsions, coma
  • Oliguria, acute renal failure
  • Circulatory failure, shock

DIC occurring in association with giant hemangiomas, where thrombi are formed within the neoplasm, is known as Kasabach-Merritt syndrome.

Management of DIC mainly involves treating the underlying cause.

Related Pearl: Causes of Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute, subacute, or chronic thrombohemorrhagic disorder occurring as a secondary complication in a variety of diseases. It is characterized by the activation of the coagulation sequence that leads to the formation of microthrombi throughout the microcirculation of the body. As a consequence of the thrombotic diathesis, there is a consumption of platelets, fibrin, and coagulation factors and, secondarily, activation of fibrinolytic mechanisms.

Causes of DIC:

Obstetric complications
  • Abruptio placenta
  • Retained dead fetus
  • Septic abortion
  • Amniotic fluid embolism
  • Toxemia
Infections
  • Sepsis
  • Meningococcemia
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Aspergillosis
  • Malaria
  • Toxemia 
Neoplasms
  • Ca. pancreas
  • Ca. prostate
  • Ca. lung
  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia
Massive Tissue Injury
  • Traumatic injury
  • Burns
  • Extensive surgery
Miscellaneous
  • Acute intravascular hemolysis
  • Snake bite
  • Shock
  • Stroke
  • Vasculitis
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Liver disease

Related Pearl: Coagulation Pathways and its Abnormalities

Test results Inherited causes Acquired causes

Prolonged PT 

Evaluates extrinsic pathway factors

Normal PT: 11-13 seconds

 Factor VII deficiency 

Mild vitamin K deficiency

Liver disease

Warfarin

Prolonged aPTT

Evaluates intrinsic pathway factors

Normal aPTT: 25-35 seconds

Factors VIII, IX, XI deficiency

Factor XII, prekallikrein, or HMW kininogen deficiency

von Willebrand disease

 Heparin, lupus anticoagulant, acquired von Willebrand disease

Prolonged PT + prolonged aPTT

Evaluates common pathway factors

Prothrombin (II), fibrinogen (I), factors V and factor X deficiencies

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

Severe liver disease

Severe vitamin K deficiency

Direct thrombin inhibitor-argatroban, dabigatran

Direct factor Xa inhibitor-rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban

Fondaparinux

 

Related Pearl: Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

 Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

Parameter Uses
Prothrombin Time (PT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the extrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal PT is 11–13 seconds.
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the intrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal aPTT is 25–35 seconds. A relatively rare cause of prolonged aPTT is the presence of antibodies against coagulation plasma proteins called inhibitors. It can be seen due to the following reasons: Hemophilia A and B patients receiving clotting factors to control their bleeding episodes, Pregnancy, Autoimmune diseases, Malignancies (lymphoma, prostate cancer), and Dermatologic conditions.
Thrombin time (TT) It is used for testing the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin and depends on adequate fibrinogen levels. 
Bleeding time (BT) It is the time taken for a standardized skin puncture to stop bleeding. It tests the ability of blood vessels to constrict and platelets to form a hemostatic plug. 
Fibrin degradation products (FDPs) They are used to assess the fibrinolytic activity, and they are increased in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

questions.text: All the following are examples of non-neoplastic polyps except:
questions.solution:
Adenomatous polyps are examples of neoplastic polyps.

GI Polyps are most common in the colo-rectal region. The most common neoplastic polyps are colonic adenomas, which are precursors to the majority of colorectal adenocarcinomas. Neoplastic polyps may be of 3 types:

  1. Tubular adenoma
  2. Villous adenoma 
  3. Tubulovillous adenoma

The non-neoplastic polyps can be further classified as

  • Hyperplastic polyp - benign epithelial proliferations
  • Inflammatory polyp - occurs following repeated injury and healing of the rectal mucosa and presents with rectal bleeding and mucus discharge
  • Hamartomatous polyp - Juvenile polyps and polyps of Peutz-Jegher Syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with a bulky scrotal swelling. On resection, the testicular mass is found to be homogenous, grey-white, and does not show hemorrhage or necrosis. The histopathological image is shown below. Which of the following is true for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histological image is suggestive of seminoma of the testes, and human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) levels may be elevated.

"Classic" or "typical" seminomas are the most common type of germ cell tumor. They are bulky, homogenous, pale, and well-circumscribed masses that do not show any hemorrhage or necrosis, as shown in the image below. 

Microscopically, sheets of uniform tumor cells divided into poorly demarcated lobules by fibrous septa are seen. Each cell is large, round, and has a distinct cell membrane, abundant clear cytoplasm, and a large central nucleus with a few nucleoli.

In about 15% of cases, serum HCG levels are raised as these seminomas contain syncytiotrophoblasts. Lactate dehdrogenase (LDH) levels are also measured to assess tumor burden.

Therapy depends on the stage of the tumor. Seminoma has the best prognosis. Most cases of seminoma stages I and II can be cured by orchiectomy with or without chemotherapy or radiotherapy.

Other options:

Option B: ɑ-fetoprotein (AFP) levels are elevated in yolk sac tumors.

Options C and D: Seminoma cells stain positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and podoplanin and negative for cytokeratin by immunohistochemistry.

Related Pearl: Tumor Markers in Testicular Germ Cell Tumors

 

AFP

b-hCG

LDH

Seminoma

 -

+

++

Yolk sac tumor

+++

+

+

Choriocarcinoma

 -

+++

+

Embryonal carcinoma

+

+

++

Teratoma

 - 

 -

 -

 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP: Raised in

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Mixed germ cell tumor

AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma (only in about 15% Seminomas)
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

Related Pearl: Seminomatous germ-cell tumors (GCTs) vs Non-seminomatous GCT

Features Seminoma Non- seminomatous GCT
Age 2nd or 3rd decade (Never seen in prepubertal children) Occur at any age
Presentation Localized to the testis for a long time Aggressive tumors; present at an advanced clinical stage
Spread Lymphatic Hematogenous
Macroscopy Homogenous Variegated
Cell type Composed of primordial germ cells Composed of undifferentiated cells
Tumor marker Placental alkaline phosphatase AFP, HCG
Radio-therapy Radiosensitive Radioresistant
Prognosis Better Poor

AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein 

HCG: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

questions.text: Mutation in alpha 5 chain of collagen 4 leads to
questions.solution:
Alport’s syndrome is due to mutations in one of several genes coding for subunits of the collagen IV molecule which is crucial for function of the GBM, the lens of the eye, and the cochlea.

  • Most common presenting sign is gross or microscopic hematuria, accompanied by red cell casts.
  • Hematuria with progression to chronic renal failure, accompanied by nerve deafness and various eye disorders, including lens dislocation, posterior cataracts, and corneal dystrophy.
  • X-linked trait in approximately 85% of cases
  • Autosomal recessive and autosomal dominant pedigrees also exist 
  • The GBM consists of networks of trimeric collagen IV molecules composed of α3, α4, and α5 chains
  • Mutations affecting any one chain result in defective assembly of the collagen network
  • Electron microscopic findings- distinctive basket-weave appearance

Thin Basement Membrane Lesion -Familial asymptomatic hematuria—Diffuse thinning of the GBM to widths between 150 and 225 nm.

Goodpasture syndrome  - anti-GBM antibodies cross-react with other basement membranes, especially those in the lung alveoli, resulting in simultaneous lung and kidney lesions The GBM antigen a component of the noncollagenous domain (NC1) of the α3 chain of type IV collagen

Type of collagen Site Disease
I Scar tissue, tendon, skin, arterial walls, cornea, fibrocartilage, bones and teeth

Osteogenesis imperfecta

Ehler Danlos syndrome

Caffeys disease
II Hyaline cartilage, vitreous humour type II and XI collagenopathies
III Granulation tissue, skin, arterial walls, intestines, uterus Ehler Danlos syndrome  
IV Basement membrane, eye lens, capillaries, glomeruli

Alports syndrome

Goodpasture syndrome
V Interstitium Classical Ehler Danlos syndrome

Basket weave appearance of glomerular basement membrane on electrom microscopy in Alports syndrome.

questions.text: The gross specimen of the pancreas from a patient who died of acute pancreatitis is shown below. What is it suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The given specimen shows yellow nodules with areas of chalky-white deposits, which are suggestive of fat necrosis.

Fat necrosis results from the release of activated pancreatic lipases into the substance of the pancreas and the peritoneal cavity. These enzymes act on surrounding tissue to release fatty acids, which then combine with calcium to produce grossly visible chalky-white areas (fat saponification).

Histologic examination reveals foci of shadowy outlines of necrotic fat cells, with basophilic calcium deposits, surrounded by an inflammatory reaction.

The various types of necrosis include:

Type Example
Coagulative necrosis Infarcts in all organs except the brain
Caseous necrosis Tuberculosis
Liquefactive necrosis

Abscesses

Brain infarct

Wet gangrene
Fat necrosis Pancreatitis, Breast
Fibrinoid necrosis

Vasculitis

Aschoff bodies

Malignant hypertension

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient with malaria is treated with primaquine. He develops fatigue and yellowish discoloration of skin and sclera. On examination, there is pallor and icterus.  The peripheral smear is as seen below. What is not true about the condition?

choices.text: It commonly presents as a chronic haemolytic anaemia
The most common triggers are infections

questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows RBCs displaying anisopoikilocytosis with polychromasia and many bite cells (arrows) suggestive of G6PD Deficiency.

Commonly G6PD deficiency presents as acute hemolysis, marked by anemia, hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria.

Uncommonly, G6PD deficiency presents as neonatal jaundice or a chronic low-grade hemolytic anemia in the absence of infection or known environmental triggers.

  • Recessive X-linked trait.
  • G6PD  deficiency - Impaired enzyme function reduce the ability of red cells to protect themselves against oxidative injuries and lead to hemolysis.
  • The episodic hemolysis that is characteristic of G6PD deficiency is caused by exposures that generate oxidant stress.
  • The most common triggers are infections
  • The oxidant drugs implicated are numerous, including antimalarials (e.g., primaquine and chloroquine), sulfonamides, nitrofurantoin, and others.
  • The most frequently cited food is the fava bean
  • Oxidants cause both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis in G6PD-deficient individuals
  • Cross-linking of reactive sulfhydryl groups on globin chains become denatured and form membrane-bound precipitates known as Heinz bodies.
  • These are seen as dark inclusions within red cells stained with crystal violet (Supravital stain)
  • Heinz bodies can damage the membrane sufficiently to cause intravascular hemolysis.
  • Bite cells and spherocytes are trapped in splenic cords and removed rapidly by phagocytes - Extravascular hemolysis
  • Protective effect against Plasmodium falciparum malaria
  • As inclusion-bearing red cells pass through the splenic cords, macrophages pluck out the Heinz bodies - Bite cells
  • Because hemolytic episodes related to G6PD deficiency occur intermittently, features related to chronic hemolysis (e.g., splenomegaly, cholelithiasis) are absent.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a tumor suppressor gene?
questions.solution:
WT-1, RB, and P53 are all examples of tumor suppressor genes. RAS is a protein involved in signal transduction.

Tumor suppressor gene products inhibit cell proliferation. Abnormalities in these genes cause a failure to inhibit uncontrolled growth which leads to carcinogenesis. Some tumor suppressor genes and associated malignancies:

Gene Function Sporadic cancers
APC Inhibitor of WNT signaling Familial colonic polyps and carcinomas
NF1 Inhibitor of RAS/MAPK signaling Neurofibromatosis type 1
NF2 Cytoskeletal stability, Hippo pathway signaling Neurofibromatosis type 2 
PTEN Inhibitor of PI3K/AKT signaling Cowden syndrome
RB Inhibitor of G1/S transition during cell cycle progression Retinoblastoma
VHL Inhibitor of hypoxia-induced transcription factors Von Hippel Lindau syndrome
STK11 Suppression of cell growth when cell nutrient and energy levels are low Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
CDH1 Cell adhesion, inhibition of cell motility Gastric carcinoma
TP53 Cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in response to DNA damage Li Fraumeni syndrome
BRCA1, BRCA2 Repair of double-stranded breaks in DNA Familial breast and ovarian carcinomas, carcinoma of male breast
MSH2, MLH1, MSH6 DNA mismatch repair Hereditary nonpolyposis colon carcinoma
WT1 Transcription factor Wilm's tumor
MEN1 Transcription factor Multiple endocrine neoplasia-1 ( MEN1- pituitary, parathyroid, and pancreatic endocrine tumors)

Related Pearl: Tumor suppressor genes

 Gene

Mechanism

Chromosome

TGF- Beta Receptor

E-cadherin

Growth inhibition 

Cell adhesion

Chromosome 19

Chromosome 16
NF1 Inhibition of RAS signal transduction and of p21 cell cycle inhibitor Chromosome 17
NF2 Cytoskeletal instability Chromosome 22

APC/Beta-catenin

 Inhibition of signal transduction Chromosome 5
PTEN Pi3 kinase signal transduction Chromosome 10
SMAD2 and SMAD4 TGF- beta signal transduction Chromosome 18
RB1 Regulation of cell cycle Chromosome 13
p53 Cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in response to DNA damage Chromosome 17

WT1

P16/INk4a

Nuclear transcription

Regulation of cell cycle by inhibition of cyclin dependent kinases

Chromosome 11

Chromosome 9
BRCA1 and BRCA2 DNA repair Chromosome 17 and 13

questions.text: A 30 year old female presents with pain in right knee since 2 months which is tender on palpation. Radiographs show a 6 cm mass in distal femoral epiphysis with soap bubble appearance. Microscopy of curetted specimen is as seen below. All are true about the tumour except:

choices.text: The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL
Majority seen around the knee joint
Up to 4% of tumors metastasize to the lungs

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is a giant cell tumor of bone. It arises in the epiphysis but may extend into the metaphysis.

Giant cell tumor of bone

  • Benign, locally aggressive, neoplasm that usually arises in individuals in their 20s to 40s.
  • The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL
  • Arise in the epiphysis but may extend into the metaphysis.
  • Majority seen arise around the knee (distal femur and proximal tibia)
  • Most are solitary
  • Sheets of uniform oval mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast-type giant cells with 100 or more nuclei. Necrosis and mitotic activity may be prominent.
  • 40% to 60% recur locally
  • Up to 4% of tumors metastasize to the lungs, but these sometimes spontaneously regress and they are seldom fatal.

 

Note:-

 Remember E mnemonic for GCT-

  • Epiphyseal
  • Eccentric
  • Eggshell crackling
  • Expansile

questions.text: Hyperacute rejection in organ transplantation is due to
questions.solution:
Hyperacute Rejection

Hyperacute rejection occurs when preformed antidonor antibodies are present in the circulation of the recipient.

  • Occurs within minutes or hours after transplantation.
  • A hyperacutely rejecting kidney rapidly becomes cyanotic, mottled, and flaccid, and may excrete a mere few drops of bloody urine. 
  • Immunoglobulin and complement are deposited in the vessel wall, causing endothelial injury and fibrin-platelet thrombi
  • Neutrophils rapidly accumulate within arterioles, glomeruli, and peritubular capillaries
  • As these changes become diffuse and intense, the glomeruli undergo thrombotic occlusion of the capillaries, and fibrinoid necrosis occurs in arterial walls.
  • The kidney cortex then undergoes outright necrosis (infarction), and such non-functioning kidneys have to be removed.

questions.text: A 50 year old female patient presents with bilateral adnexal masses and ascites. Histopathological examination of resected adnexal masses reveals sheets of mucin producing signet ring cells as seen below.  The most likely primary site of the tumour is
questions.solution:
The most likely  diagnosis is a metastatic signet ring carcinoma called Krukenberg tumour. Stomach is the primary site in most Krukenberg tumor cases (70%). Carcinomas of colon, appendix, and breast (mainly invasive lobular carcinoma) are the next most common primary sites.

  • Krukenberg tumor is a metastatic signet ring cell adenocarcinoma of the ovary accounting for 1% to 2% of all ovarian tumors
  • Microscopically, it is composed chiefly of mucin-laden signet ring cells with eccentric hyperchromatic nuclei.
  • Mitotic activity is sparse. The signet ring cells can be single, clustered, nested, or they can be arranged in tubules, acini, trabeculae, or cords.

questions.text: An incidental, rounded radio-opacity (coin lesion) is discovered on a routine chest film. The lesion is resected and microscopy is as seen below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows epithelial clefts lined by ciliated columnar epithelium or nonciliated epithelium with mature adipose tissue and benign cartilage.

The most likely diagnosis is pulmonary hamartoma.

  • Most common benign tumor of the lung, most often with a chondromatous element.
  • A relatively common lesion that is usually discovered as an incidental, rounded radio-opacity (coin lesion) on a routine chest film.
  • Typically solitary, <4 cm, composed of disordered but mature hyaline cartilage, fibrous tissue, smooth muscle, fat, sometimes with calcification/ossification.
  • Cartilage is the most common connective tissue.
  • The epithelial clefts are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium or nonciliated epithelium and probably represent entrapment of respiratory epithelium.
  • Nonfamilial Carney triad: Pulmonary chondroma, gastric stromal tumors, functional extra-adrenal paraganglioma.

questions.text: Best investigation among the following for diagnosing amyloidosis  in the GI tract is:
questions.solution:
Best investigation for diagnosing amyloidosis in the GI tract is a rectal biopsy. 

The best sites of biopsy:

  • Gingiva
  • Rectal mucosa

questions.text: The most common Non Hodgkin lymphoma presenting as lymphomatoid polyposis is
questions.solution:
• Multifocal mucosal involvement of the small bowel and colon produces lymphomatoid polyposis.
  • LP most commonly represents mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) of the GI tract; however, some cases of follicular lymphoma (FL) and MALT lymphoma of the GI tract are found with a multiple polypoid appearance.

questions.text: Which of these is a potent suppressor of inflammation?
questions.solution:
Lipoxins

Lipoxins are also generated from AA by the lipoxygenase pathway, but unlike prostaglandins and leukotrienes, the lipoxins suppress inflammation by inhibiting the recruitment of leukocytes. They inhibit neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion to endothelium.

questions.text: Which of the following tumours of thyroid arises from C cells?
questions.solution:
Medullary Carcinoma arises from C cells of thyroid gland.

Classification of thyroid neoplasms

Primary

Follicular epithelium

  • Papillary 
  • Follicular
  • Hurthle cell
  • Anaplastic

Parafollicular (C-cells)

  • Medullary

Lymphoid cells

  • Lymphoma

Metastatic

  • Medullary carcinomas of the thyroid are neuroendocrine neoplasms derived from the parafollicular cells, or C cells, of the thyroid
  • Account for approximately 5% of thyroid neoplasms
  • Occurs in the setting of MEN syndrome 2A or 2B or as familial tumors without an associated MEN syndrome
  • Activating point mutations in the RET proto-oncogene
  • Bilaterality and multicentricity are common in familial cases
  • Histopathology - Polygonal to spindle-shaped cells, which may form nests, trabeculae, and even follicles
  • Acellular amyloid deposits derived from calcitonin polypeptides are present in the stroma in many cases
  • Calcitonin is readily demonstrable within the cytoplasm of the tumor cells as well as in the stromal amyloid by immunohistochemical methods.
  • Electron microscopy - Variable numbers of membrane-bound electron-dense granules within the cytoplasm of the neoplastic cells
  • Familial medullary Carcinoma -Multicentric C-cell hyperplasia in the surrounding thyroid parenchyma, believed to be a precursor lesion in familial cases.

questions.text: A child presents with features of diabetes insipidus, proptosis, and radiographic defects in skull bones. A bone biopsy reveals that the lesions consist of eosinophils and dendritic cells as seen below. Electron microscopy is likely to reveal
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows proliferating Langerhans cells with abundant, often vacuolated cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei containing linear grooves or folds  and surrounding eosinophils. The most likely diagnosis is Langerhan cell histiocytosis. The triad of  diabetes insipidus, proptosis, and radiographic defects in skull bones is called Hand-Schüller-Christian triad.  An electron micrograph is likely to show rodlike Birbeck granules with characteristic periodicity and dilated terminal end.

  • The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
  • Birbeck granules are pentalaminar tubules, often with a dilated terminal end producing a tennis racket-like appearance which contain the protein langerin.
  • In addition, the tumor cells also typically express HLA-DR, S-100, and CD1a.

Birbeck granules in Langerhans cell histiocytosis

  • Lamellated myeloid or zebra bodies are seen in Tay-Sachs disease, metachromatic leukodystrophy, Fabry’s disease,  mucolipidoses and  mucopolysaccharidoses  and in zebra body myopathy.
  • Flocculent densities in mitochondria are seen in irreversible cell injury
  • Beta pleated sheet is seen in amyloidosis

questions.text: Psammoma bodies are seen in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Psammoma bodies are not seen in phaeochromocytomas

Psammoma bodies are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by

  1. Infarction and calcification of papillae tips
  2. Calcification of intralymphatic tumor thrombi

Psammoma bodies in Tumors:

  1. Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  2. Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  3. Ovarian papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma
  4. Endometrial adenocarcinoma (Papillary Serous Carcinoma)
  5. Meningiomas
  6. Mesothelioma
  7. Somatostatinoma
  8. Prolactinoma

Psammoma bodies in Benign Conditions:

  1. Endosalpingiosis
  2. Psammomatous melanotic schwannoma
  3. Melanocytic nevus

Psammoma body: a product of dystrophic calcification or of a biologically active process that aims at limiting the growth and spread of a tumor.

Psammoma bodies, H and E stain.

questions.text: RB(Retinoblastoma) induces cell cycle arrest at which checkpoint of cell cycle?
questions.solution:
When hypophosphorylated, RB exerts antiproliferative effects by binding and inhibiting E2F transcription factors that regulate genes required for cells to pass through the G1-S phase cell cycle checkpoint.

  • RB- Inhibitor of G1/S transition during cell cycle progression
  • Familial retinoblastoma syndrome(retinoblastoma, osteosarcoma, other sarcomas)
  • Knudsons two hit hypothesis
  • Antiproliferative effect of RB is abrogated in cancers through a variety of mechanisms, including:
    • Antiproliferative effect of RB is abrogated in cancers through a variety of mechanisms, including:
    • Loss-of-function mutations affecting RB
    • Gene amplifications of CDK4 and cyclin D genes
    • Loss of cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors (p16/INK4a)
    • Viral oncoproteins that bind and inhibit RB (E7 protein of HPV)

questions.text: All of the following may be seen in the accelerated phase of Chronic myelogenous leukemia except:

choices.text: Increasing splenomegaly or white blood cell count while on therapy

questions.solution:
In the accelerated phase of CML, 10 - 19% blasts are seen in blood or marrow.

  • Chronic phase for 3-4 years
  • 50% have accelerated phase
    • 10 - 19% blasts in blood or marrow
    • persistent platelet count < 100K or > 1000K 
    • increasing splenomegaly or white blood cell count while on therapy
    • marked myelofibrosis
    • additional or clonal cytogenetic abnormalities with lack of response to treatment
  • Blast transformation (phase) at mean 3 years after diagnosis
    • ->20% blasts

questions.text: The red cell inclusions seen below in the smear are
questions.solution:
Peripheral blood smear preparation with standard Wright-Giemsa stain shows smooth, round basophilic (purple) particles in eosinophilic erythrocytes suggestive of Howell Jolly bodies

Howell-Jolly bodies persist in those with functional hyposplenism or asplenia:

  • Autosplenectomy due to sickle cell anemia
  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS)
  • Radiation therapy
  • Severe hemolytic anemia
  • Splenectomy following trauma

 

Papenheimer bodies -irregular abnormal granules of iron seen as basophilic erythrocytic inclusions usually located at periphery

  •  Thalassemia
  •  Sideroblastic anemia
  •  Hemolytic anemia

 

Heinz bodies contain Denatured Hb that appears purple-blue on the supravital stain

  • G6PD deficiency
  • Unstable HB

 

Cabot rings are made of microtubules remnants from a mitotic spindle

  • Asplenia
  • Lead poisoning
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Thalassemia

Related Pearl: Pathological Named Bodies

Bodies Found in
Asteroid bodies Sarcoidosis, Sporotrichosis

Halberstaedter–Prowazek bodies

questions.text: A chronically ill patient is found to have anemia. All the following are true about anemia of chronic disease except:

choices.text: May be seen in association with Hodgkin lymphoma
Interleukin-6 stimulates increase in production of hepcidin in this condition
Low serum ferritin and increased  total iron-binding capacity is seen
Abundant stored iron in tissue macrophages is seen

questions.solution:
Anemia of chronic disease shows high serum ferritin and reduced total iron-binding capacity.

Chronic diseases that produce persistent systemic inflammation can impair red cell production and thus cause anemia of chronic disease. This is due to decreased proliferation of erythroid progenitors and impaired iron utilization.

The chronic illnesses associated with  anemia of chronic disease can be grouped into three categories:

  1. Chronic microbial infections- osteomyelitis, bacterial endocarditis, and lung abscess
  2. Chronic immune disorders- rheumatoid arthritis and regional enteritis
  3. Neoplasms- breast and lung carcinomas, Hodgkin lymphoma

Many effects of inflammation are related to the abnormalities seen in anemia of chronic disease. Inflammatory mediators, like interleukin-6 (IL-6), stimulate the production of hepcidin. Hepcidin inhibits ferroportin in macrophages. This reduces the transfer of iron from the storage pool to the bone marrow, where erythroid precursors are developing. In addition, erythroid progenitors cannot proliferate adequately because erythropoietin levels are inappropriately low for the level of anemia.

Clinical features include mild anemia, with the symptoms of the underlying disease. The red cells may be normocytic and normochromic, or hypochromic and microcytic. Increased storage iron in marrow macrophages, high serum ferritin, and a decreased total iron-binding capacity readily rule out the iron deficiency when the smear shows a microcytic hypochromic picture.

Related Pearl: Morphological Classification of Anemias

 

Microcytic Hypochromic

(MCV <80 fl)

Normocytic Normochromic    

(MCV 80 - 100 fl)

Macrocytic Normochromic

(MCV >100 fl)

Iron deficiency anemia

Sideroblastic anemia

Thalassemia

Lead toxicity

Acute blood loss

Anemia of chronic disease

Anemia of renal disease

Hemolysis*

Bone marrow suppression

  • Aplastic anemia
  • Pure red cell aplasia

 

  

Megaloblastic:

Vitamin B12 deficiency

Folate deficiency

Thiamine deficiency

Drugs - Methotrexate, Zidovudine, hydroxyurea

Orotic aciduria

 

Non-megaloblastic:

Alcohol use

Liver disease

Hypothyroidism

Hemolysis*

 

*Hemolysis can be associated with macrocytosis because of compensatory reticulocytosis. However, MCV can be normal depending on the degree of hemolysis.

Note: In Orotic Aciduria, peripheral blood smear shows Hypochromic megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A 70 year old male is diagnosed with a brain tumor arising in the white matter. The tumor appears to be rapidly expanding, gray, and poorly defined. Microscopic examination of his brain tumour is as seen below. It is determined that the patient will only survive for a few months. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Glioblastoma (previously called glioblastoma multiforme)

  • Rapidly growing tumour – WHO Grade IV
  • Pseudopalisading necrosis and vascular/endothelial cell proliferation with Glomeruloid body
  • VEGF, produced by malignant astrocytes in response to hypoxia, contributes to this distinctive vascular change
  • Gliomatosis cerebri is a diffuse glioma with extensive infiltration of multiple regions of the brain, in some cases the entire brain
  • Meningioma- Whorls, psammoma bodies
  • Oligodendroglioma- Honeycomb appearance, fried egg cells, perinuclear halo, chicken wire capillaries, calcification
  • Lymphoma- Immunosupression, EBV associated, multifocal, DLBCL most common subtype

questions.text: A pathologist is studying the following slide from the biopsy of a patient with an abdominal mass. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathology slide shows nests of cells arranged in an organoid pattern, with fibrovascular septae, and finely granular cytoplasm. This is called the zellballen pattern. It is typically seen in paragangliomas and pheochromocytomas.

Paragangliomas are benign neuroendocrine tumors arising from paraganglia in the neck or abdomen. They are composed of chief and sustentacular cells arranged in an organoid pattern.

questions.text: A 7-month-old male infant was brought with a 2-day history of fever and abscess over the neck. The mother reveals that the child has had similar recurrent infections in the past. The result of the nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction test was found to be abnormal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and abnormal nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction test are suggestive of chronic granulomatous disease (CGD).

CGD is a rare primary immunodeficiency of phagocytes. It is an X-linked recessive disorder due to the deficiency in the NADPH oxidase enzyme. This is important in the respiratory or oxidative burst. 

It usually manifests in the first year of life with recurrent pyogenic infections with catalase-positive organisms, including: 

  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Escherichia coli
  • Aspergillus species

Related Pearl: Chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to the defect in NADPH oxidase. This interferes with the killing of bacteria by oxidative burst. Hence, the patients are at increased risk of infection from catalase-positive bacteria.

 It can be:

  • X linked - Defect in one of the membrane-bound components (gp91phox) or
  • Autosomal recessive - Cytoplasmic components (p47phox and p67phox)

Diagnosis of CGD includes:

  • Nitroblue tetrazolium test - This is the standard for phagocyte oxidase activity measurement. The colorless compound NBT is reduced to blue formazan by the activity of the functional phox enzyme system. Normally, more than 95% of the granulocytes will be positive. The NBT is negative in CGD due to absence of phox enzyme activity.
  • Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test - The most accurate diagnostic test for CGD. Normally functioning phagocytic cells oxidize DHR to the strongly fluorescent compound rhodamine which is quantified by flow cytometry.

questions.text: The cardinal sign of inflammation called rubor is mainly the consequence of
questions.solution:
Rubor is due to increased blood flow as a result of vasodilatation and increased permeability of arterioles.

Changes in Vascular Flow and Caliber

Vasodilation is induced by the action of several mediators

It is one of the earliest manifestations of acute inflammation.

Vasodilation first involves the arterioles and then leads to opening of new capillary beds in the area.

The result is increased blood flow, which is the cause of heat and redness (erythema) at the site of inflammation. (rubor)

Latin term English term  Primary cause
Rubor  Redness Histamine release
Calor  Heat 
Tumor  Swelling
Dolor  Pain Bradykinin and PGE2

questions.text: What is Dicer?
questions.solution:
• Dicer is an enzyme that cleaves mi RNA and involved in gene silencing
  • Dicer enzyme trims the pre-miRNA to generate mature double-stranded miRNAs of 21 to 30 nucleotides.

questions.text: The cross-section of the brain of an 84-year-old man with dyslipidemia is given below, in comparison with a normal brain. Which of the following is the most likely pathological change?
questions.solution:
The given image shows narrowing of gyri and widening of sulci in a senile brain, which is suggestive of senile atrophy. It is due to a gradual decrease in blood supply as a result of atherosclerosis, known as ischemic atrophy.

The various types of pathological atrophy are:

Pathologic atrophy 
Disuse atrophy (decreased workload) Atrophy in a limb that has been immobilized following a fracture
Denervation atrophy (loss of nerve supply) Skeletal muscle atrophy following nerve injury
Ischemic atrophy Senile atrophy of the brain and heart due to atherosclerosis
Inadequate nutrition Severe muscle wasting in marasmus
Pressure atrophy Atrophy of surrounding uninvolved tissues caused by an enlarging benign tumor

questions.text: Acridine orange is a fluorescent dye used to bind:
questions.solution:
Acridine orange is a nucleic acid selective fluorescent cationic dye useful for cell cycle discrimination. This dye permeates the cell and is a nucleic acid stain which after binding to dsDNA emits green fluorescence and when it binds to RNA or ssDNA emits red fluorescence.

The Acridine orange can be used along with ethidium bromide to differentiate between living and apoptotic cells.

questions.text: Dense granules of platelets contain all except
questions.solution:
TGF Beta is not found within dense granules of platelets.

Dense (or δ) granules contain:

  • adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and adenosine triphosphate,
  • ionized calcium,
  • histamine,
  • serotonin
  • epinephrine.

questions.text: Who discovered the process of phagocytosis?
questions.solution:
Ilya Ilyich Mechnikov discovered the process of phagocytosis. He is known as the father of natural immunity and established the concept of cell-mediated immunity.

He was jointly awarded the 1908 Nobel Prize in Physiology along with Paul Ehrlich, who established the concept of humoral immunity.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about mucopolysaccharidosis?

choices.text: Hunter syndrome is due to a deficiency of iduronate 2-sulphatase
Hurler syndrome is due to a deficiency of α-L-iduronidase
They are inherited as autosomal recessive traits, except Hunter syndrome
Hunter syndrome is inherited as an autosomal dominant disease

questions.solution:
All the mucopolysaccharidoses are inherited as autosomal-recessive traits except Hunter syndrome. It is inherited as an X-linked recessive disease.

The mucopolysaccharidoses (MPSs) are a group of closely related syndromes that result from genetically determined deficiencies of enzymes involved in the degradation of mucopolysaccharides (glycosaminoglycans).

Mucopolysaccharides are abundant in the ground substance of connective tissues. In the absence of enzymes involved in their degradation, they accumulate within lysosomes in various tissues and organs of the body. Two among these are:

  • Hurler syndrome - deficiency of α-L-iduronidase
  • Hunter syndrome - deficiency of iduronate 2-sulphatase
 

Related Pearl: MPS and Their Respective Enzyme Deficiencies

Disease MPS Enzyme defective GAGs affected Symptoms
Hurler-, Scheie-, 
Hurler-scheie syndrome		 MPS I α-L-Iduronidase

Dermatan sulfate,
Heparan sulfate

 Mental retardation,
coarse facial features, 
Hepatosplenomegaly
Cloudy cornea
Hunter syndrome MPS II Iduronate sulfatase Dermatan sulfate, 
Heparan sulfate		 Mental retardation
Sanfilippo syndrome A MPS IIIA Heparan sulfate-N-sulfatase Heparan sulfate Delay in development
Motor dysfunction
Sanfilippo syndrome B MPS III B α-N-Acetylglucosaminidase Heparan sulfate As MPS III A
Sanfilippo syndrome C MPS III C α-glucosaminide N-acetyltransferase Heparan sulfate As MPS III A  
Sanfilippo syndrome D MPS III D N-acetylglucosamine 6-sulfatase Heparan sulfate As MPS III A  
Morquio syndrome A MPS IV A Galactosamine 6-sulfatase Keratan sulfate 
Chondroitin 6-sulfate 		 Skeletal dysplasia
short stature
Morquio syndrome B MPS IV B β-galactosidase Keratan sulfate As MPS IV A
Maroteaux-lamy syndrome  MPS VI N-acetylgalactosamine 4-sulfatase Dermatan sulfate Curvature of the spine,
Short stature
Skeletal dysplasia
Cardiac defects
Sly syndrome  MPS VII β-glucuronidase Dermatan sulfate
Heparan sulfate
Chondroitin 4-sulfate 
Chondroitin 6-sulfate 

 Short stature
Skeletal dysplasia
Hepatomegaly
Cloudy cornea
Natowicz syndrome  MPS IX Hyaluronidase Hyaluronic acid Joint Pain
Short stature

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with sudden onset chorea and behavioral changes. Genetic investigation reveals CAG repeats. What is the mode of inheritance of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Huntington's disease. It is an autosomal-dominant inherited disorder.

Huntington disease (HD) also known as Huntington chorea is associated with CAG repeats and anticipation. It has an adult-onset and cell loss within a specific subset of neurons in the basal ganglia and cortex is seen. The characteristic features of HD include involuntary movements, dementia, and behavioral changes.

Related Pearl: Inheritance pattern of important diseases

Autosomal dominant
Autosomal recessive
HEAVy DOMINANT
ABC DEF GHI
H: Hereditary spherocytosis, Hypercholesterolemia, Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy,  Huntington’s disease
A: Ataxia-telangiectasia, Albinism, Alkaptonuria, 
Autosomal-recessive polycystic kidney disease
E: Ehler-Danlos syndrome
B: Blood disorders like beta-thalassemia and sickle-cell anemia
A: Achondroplasia
C: Cystic fibrosis, 
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia
V: Von Willebrand disease, Von Hippel Lindau disease
D: Sensorineural deafness
D: Dystrophia myotonica
E: Emphysema 
(alpha1- antitrypsin deficiency)
O: Osteogenesis imperfecta, Otosclerosis (variable)
F: Friedrich ataxia
M: Marfans syndrome, Multiple endocrine neoplasias (MEN)
G: Gaucher’s disease, Galactosemia, glycogen storage diseases
I: Intermittent porphyria
H: Homocystinuria, Hemochromatosis
N: Neurofibromatosis 1 and 2
I: Inborn errors of metabolism- Phenylketonuria, lysosomal storage diseases
A: Autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease Other conditions: Wilson's disease, sickle cell anemia, thalassemias, spinal muscular atrophy, Kartagener syndrome, 
N: Noonan's syndrome Mucopolysaccharidoses (except Hunter syndrome)
T: Tuberous sclerosis Sphingolipidoses (except Fabry disease)
Other conditions: Familial adenomatous polyposis, Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, Li-Fraumeni syndrome, Pseudohypoparathyroidism

(Red) Rett’s syndrome
(Hardinge) Hunter's syndrome, Hemophilia A and B

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

questions.text: Sialyl-Lewis X is linked to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Sialyl-Lewis X refers to sialylated oligosaccharides bound to mucin-like glycoprotein. These molecules function as ligands for selectins.

The expression of selectins and their ligands is regulated by cytokines produced in response to infection and injury.

Related Pearl: Selectins and Associated Ligands

Molecule

Distribution

Ligand

L- selectin (CD62L)

Neutrophils, monocytes

T cells (naïve and central memory)

B cells (naïve)

Sialyl–Lewis X/PNAd on GlyCAM-1, CD34, MAdCAM-1 Others; expressed on endothelium (HEV)

E- selectin (CD62E)

Endothelium activated by cytokines (TNF, IL-1

Sialyl–Lewis X (e.g., CLA) on glycoproteins; expressed on neutrophils, monocytes, T cells (effector, memory)

P- selectin (CD62P)

Endothelium activated by cytokines (TN, IL-1), histamine, or thrombin

Sialyl–Lewis X on PSGL- 1 and other glycoproteins; expressed on neutrophils, monocytes, T cells (effector, memory)

questions.text: A diabetic patient with chronic kidney disease has been undergoing hemodialysis for the past 4 years. Deposition of which of the following is likely in this condition?
questions.solution:
Patients on long-term hemodialysis for renal failure can develop amyloidosis as a result of the deposition of β2-microglobulin.

This protein is present in high concentrations in the serum of persons with renal disease. The protein is retained in the circulation because it cannot be filtered through the dialysis membranes.

It gets deposited in the synovium, joints, and tendon sheaths. When this deposition takes place in the carpal ligament of the wrist, it leads to the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.

With new dialysis filters, the incidence of this complication has decreased substantially.

questions.text: The heart of a patient who had suffered a myocardial infarction is subjected to a histopathological examination. The microscopic image is given below. What time following infarction would you observe this?
questions.solution:
The given image shows neutrophilic infiltration into the myocardium. Early neutrophil infiltration starts by 12–24 hours following the infarction. It can be visualised by examination with a light microscope.

The necrotic myocardium elicits acute inflammation most prominent between 1 and 3 days. During this time, there is a brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils.

The image given below shows neutrophilic infiltration into the myocardium following MI.

Related Pearl: The Temporal Evolution of the Morphologic Changes in Acute MI

Time

Gross Features

Microscopy features

Reversible Injury

0-1/2 hr

None

EM: Relaxation of myofibrils; glycogen loss; mitochondrial swelling

LM: None

Irreversible Injury 

1/2-4 hr

None

EM: Sarcolemmal disruption; mitochondrial amorphous densities

LM: Usually none; variable waviness of fibers at border

4-12 hr

Dark mottling (occasional)

LM: Early coagulation necrosis, edema, hemorrhage

12-24 hr

Dark mottling

LM: Ongoing coagulation necrosis, pyknosis of nuclei, myocyte hypereosinophilia, marginal contraction band necrosis, early neutrophilic infiltrate

1-3 days

Mottling with yellow-tan infarct center

LM: Coagulation necrosis, with loss of nuclei and striations, brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils

3-7 days

Hyperemic border, central yellow-tan softening

LM: Begining disintegration of dead myofibres, with dying neutrophils, early phagocytosis of dead cells by macrophages at the infarct border

7-10 days

Maximally yellow-tan and soft with depressed red-tan margins

LM: Well-developed phagocytosis of dead cells; granulation tissue at margins

10-14 days

Red-grey depressed infarct borders

LM: Well-established granulation tissue with new blood vessels and collagen deposition

2-8 wk

Grey-white scar, progressive from the  border towards the core of the infarct

LM: increased collagen deposition, with decreased cellularity

>2 mo

Scarring complete

LM: Dense collagenous scar

EM: Electron microscopy

LM: Light microscopy

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who came for a routine check-up was incidentally found to have a late systolic murmur with a mid-systolic click. Echocardiography revealed thickening and redundancy of mitral leaflets with bulging into the left atrium. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and echocardiography findings are suggestive of mitral valve prolapse (MVP) or Barlow syndrome. It is not associated with degenerative calcified deposits (seen in calcific valvular degeneration, not MVP).

Barlow syndrome is more common in females. It may be an isolated condition or less commonly can be associated with connective tissue disorders like Marfan's syndrome.

In this condition, there is mitral annular dilatation with floppy mitral valve leaflets. They prolapse or balloon back into the left atrium during systole. The following pathological changes are seen:

  • Interchordal ballooning (hooding) of the mitral leaflets
  • Thick, rubbery, redundant leaflets 
  • Thickened mural endocardium

The main histologic change is marked thickening of the spongiosa layer with deposition of mucoid called myxomatous degeneration.

Most individuals diagnosed with MVP are asymptomatic. On auscultation, a mid-systolic click, sometimes followed by a mid to late systolic murmur is heard. Chest pain mimicking angina and dyspnea occur rarely.

The complications include:

  • Infective endocarditis
  • Mitral insufficiency
  • Stroke or other systemic infarcts
  • Arrhythmias
  • Sudden cardiac death (rarely)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with hematuria, intermittent hemoptysis and chronic sinusitis. His chest radiograph shows multiple opacities and cavities. Renal biopsy suggests focal necrotizing glomerulonephritis. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?

choices.text: Necrotizing granulomas of the upper respiratory tract

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Wegener's granulomatosis. It is associated with PR3- ANCA (and not MPO- ANCA) in about 95% of cases.

Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis/Wegener granulomatosis is a necrotizing vasculitis characterized by a triad of necrotizing inflammation:

  • Necrotizing granulomas of the upper respiratory tract or the lung
  • Necrotizing or granulomatous vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels, most prominently in the lungs
  • Focal necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis

Males are affected more often than females. The most common clinical features include persistent pneumonitis with bilateral nodular and cavitary infiltrates, chronic sinusitis, mucosal ulcerations of the nasopharynx, and evidence of renal disease.

Image: Chest radiograph showing pulmonary granulomatosis

Related Pearl: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (previously called Wegener’s granulomatosis) is a necrotising vasculitis of small arteries and veins along with granuloma formation.

It presents as a triad of upper and lower respiratory tract involvement with glomerulonephritis.

Important organs involved are:

  • Upper respiratory tract- Presents with paranasal sinus pain, serous otitis media, nasal septal perforation.
  • Lower respiratory tract- Presents with cough, hemoptysis, and multiple bilateral cavitary nodular infiltrates.
  • Renal- Presents with rapidly progressive renal failure, crescentic glomerulonephritis.
  • Eye- Presents with conjunctivitis, scleritis, episcleritis and dacryocystitis
  • Skin- Papules, vesicles, palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules.

Histopathology shows necrotizing vasculitis of small arteries and vein with granuloma formation.

The important laboratory features are elevated ESR, positive cANCA  antibodies and mild elevation of rheumatoid factor.

Treatment:

  • Induction phase- Cyclophosphamide combined with steroids
  • Remission phase- Methotrexate/Azathioprine

questions.text: Which of the following pathological changes occurs in the small vessels of patients suffering from hypertension?
questions.solution:
Hypertension results in hyaline arteriolosclerosis of the small vessels.

Hypertension leads to a variety of vascular pathologies. In small blood vessels, hypertension may lead to arteriosclerosis which is the thickening of the vessel wall. It has two variants which are hyaline arteriosclerosis and hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.

In large and medium-sized arteries, hypertension leads to degenerative changes in the vessel walls, leading to:

  • Dissection
  • Aneurysm formation
  • Cerebrovascular hemorrhage
  • Acceleration of atherosclerosis

questions.text: In patients with testicular tumors, what lymph nodes are primarily involved?
questions.solution:
Retroperitoneal para-aortic nodes are the first to be involved in the lymphatic spread of testicular tumors.

Testicular tumors have a characteristic mode of spread:

  • Lymphatic spread is common to all forms of testicular tumors. Initially, it spreads to retroperitoneal para-aortic nodes, then spreads to the mediastinal and supraclavicular nodes.
  • Hematogenous spread is primarily to the lungs, but the liver, brain, and bones may also be involved.

questions.text: Patients with sickle cell disease are particularly susceptible to osteomyelitis caused by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Salmonella enteritidis is commonly implicated in osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell anemia.

The common causative organisms include:
  • Staphylococcus aureus - the most common cause overall
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa - most common cause in IV drug abusers
  • Salmonella - most common in patients of sickle cell anemia
  • Haemophilus influenzae - was a common causative organism in children, less common now due to vaccination
  • Streptococcus pyogenes - neonates
  • Escherichia coli, Klebsiella- most common cause in patients with genitourinary tract infections

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criterion to distinguish leiomyosarcoma from leiomyoma?
questions.solution:
The size of the tumor is not a criterion to distinguish between leiomyosarcoma and leiomyoma.

The following features are seen in leiomyosarcomas:

  • Mitotic index - ≥10 mitoses / 10 hpf 
  • Nuclear atypia - in the presence of nuclear atypia, 5 mitoses / 10 hpf 
  • Tumor cell necrosis - 
    • Characterized by an abrupt transition from viable to non-viable areas
    • Within the necrotic zones, atypical cells can be seen

questions.text: All of the following are true for desquamative interstitial pneumonia except that _________.

choices.text: It is always seen in smokers.
It has an excellent response to steroids.

questions.solution:
Desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP) is equally common in men and women.

Desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP)

  • It is characterized by large collections of macrophages containing dusty brown pigment (smokers’ macrophages) in the airspaces.
  • The macrophages were originally thought to be desquamated pneumocytes, thus it is a misnomer.
  • Virtually all patients are cigarette smokers.
  • It is seen in the fourth or fifth decade of life. 
  • It is equally common in men and women.
  • Clinical presentation includes insidious onset of dyspnoea and dry cough, often associated with clubbing of the digits.
  • Excellent response to steroid therapy and cessation of smoking is seen.
  • Occasionally, DIP may progress to interstitial fibrosis.

questions.text: A young man presents to your clinic with the following finding. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The image given depicts gynecomastia. Seminoma is not a cause of this condition.

Gynecomastia occurs due to increased estrogenic action. The most common causes of gynecomastia include: 

  • Cirrhosis of the liver
  • Alcohol
  • Marijuana, heroin
  • Antiretroviral therapy
  • Anabolic steroids
  • Klinefelter syndrome (XXY karyotype)
  • Functioning testicular neoplasms such as Leydig cell or Sertoli cell tumors

Microscopically, there is an increase in the dense collagenous connective tissue. It is associated with epithelial hyperplasia of the duct lining with characteristic tapering micro-papillae. Lobule formation is almost never observed.

questions.text: A biopsy from a chronic oropharyngeal lesion of a patient showed the following. Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows keratinous pearls and atypical tumor cells suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Human papillomavirus (HPV) subtypes 5 and 8 may predispose to squamous cell carcinoma, but not Epstein–Barr virus (EBV).

Risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma:

  • Exposure to UV light
  • HPV subtypes 5 and 8
  • Epidermodysplasia verruciformis
  • Industrial carcinogens (tars and oils)
  • Chronic ulcers and draining osteomyelitis
  • Old burn scars (Marjolin ulcers)
  • Ingestion of arsenicals
  • Ionizing radiation
  • Tobacco and betel nut chewing (in the oral cavity)
  • Precursor lesions:
    • Actinic keratosis
    • Xeroderma pigmentosum

The image below shows an SCC lesion in the oral cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following features would you least expect to see in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.solution:
Hemoglobinuria is not seen in hereditary spherocytosis where extravascular hemolysis occurs. It is a feature of intravascular hemolysis. Pigment gallstones, pallor and splenomegaly can be seen in this condition.

Cinical features of extravascular hemolysis include:

  • Anaemia
  • Jaundice
  • Splenomegaly

Causes of extravascular hemolysis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Thalassemia
  • Sickle cell anaemia

Note: G6PD deficiency and autoimmune hemolytic anaemia can cause both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

questions.text: In a patient with lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma, cells are found to be positive for which of the following marker?
questions.solution:
Nodular-lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin Lymphomas have Reed Sternberg cells(aka L&H CELL) that are BCL-6 positive & CD 20 positive and CD 15 & CD 30 negative.

Note:

  • CD30 is the most sensitive marker of Reed–Sternberg cell.
  • PAX5 is the most specific marker of Reed–Sternberg cell.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman, on treatment for chronic lymphocytic leukemia, notices rapidly growing swellings in her neck and axilla. She also complains of fever and weight loss. The physician suspects a transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. What is this condition called?
questions.solution:
The transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)/ small lymphocytic leukemia (SLL) to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma is called Richter syndrome. It is seen in approximately 5% to 10% of the cases.

Option B: Chédiak–Higashi syndrome is an autosomal-recessive disorder that arises from a mutation of a lysosomal trafficking regulator protein. It leads to a decrease in phagocytosis, recurrent pyogenic infections, albinism, and peripheral neuropathy.

Sézary syndrome (SS) is a triad of erythroderma, generalized lymphadenopathy, and the presence of clonally related neoplastic T cells. These cells have cerebriform nuclei (Sézary cells) and are seen in the skin, lymph nodes, and peripheral blood.

Kostmann's syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by severe neutropenia. It is associated with mutations in G-CSF.

questions.text: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is caused by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is an encephalitis caused by the JC polyomavirus.

The disease occurs almost exclusively in immunosuppressed individuals, most commonly among patients with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). The most prominent symptoms are clumsiness, progressive weakness, and visual, speech, and personality changes.

Since the virus preferentially infects oligodendrocytes, demyelin­ation is its principal pathologic effect. It affects the subcortical white matter, particularly that of the parietal and occipital lobes. On microscopic examination, enlarged oligodendrocyte nuclei containing glassy amphophilic viral inclusions are seen.

The image below shows a brain biopsy of a progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy patient, showing oligodendrocytes with nuclear enlargement and glassy chromatin.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with chronic low back pain. On examination, he has pallor and bony tenderness. A skeletal radiographic survey reveals several punched-out lytic lesions. Serum protein electrophoresis shows an M band in the gamma globulin region. Which of the following is not associated with a poor prognosis in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of multiple myeloma. Translocations involving cyclin D1 are associated with a good outcome in this condition.

t(14;16), deletions of 17p, and t(14;20) are associated with a more aggressive course.

Related Pearl: Prognostic Factors in Myeloma

Poor prognosis

Good prognosis

t(4;14), MAF translocations t(14;16) and t(14;20), del(17p), aneuploidy, hypodiploidy

Hyperdiploid, t(11;14), t(6;14), cyclin D1 or D3 positive

Elevated beta-2 microglobulin, lactate dehydrogenase, C- reactive protein, plasma-cell proliferation, or bone marrow infiltration

Plasmablastic morphology

Abnormalities by conventional cytogenetics

Plasma labelling index >3%

Serum creatinine level >2mg/dL

Bone marrow biopsy: Diffuse and prominent angiogenesis

Low serum albumin
